body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When installing, upgrading, or doing `brew info powershell`, we're given the message:
```
To use Homebrew in PowerShell, set:
  Add-Content -Path $PROFILE.CurrentUserAllHosts -Value '$(/usr/local/bin/brew shellenv) | Invoke-Expression'
```

When trying this from pwsh I get the error:
`Add-Content: Could not find a part of the path '/Users/louis/.config/powershell/profile.ps1'.`

I do not have a "powershell" directory in `~/.config`.

Is this even necessary? I ask because brew seems to working from PowerShell anyway:
```
PS /Users/louis> brew update
Updated 2 taps (homebrew/core and homebrew/cask).
==> New Formulae
mbt
==> Updated Casks
lunar
```

### Expected behavior

```console
PS> Add-Content -Path $PROFILE.CurrentUserAllHosts -Value '$(/usr/local/bin/brew shellenv) | Invoke-Expression'
PS>
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> Add-Content -Path $PROFILE.CurrentUserAllHosts -Value '$(/usr/local/bin/brew shellenv) | Invoke-Expression'    
Add-Content: Could not find a part of the path '/Users/louis/.config/powershell/profile.ps1'.
PS>

```

@TravisEz13, @SteveL-MSFT, and @andschwa, can one of you comment whether that is really necessary?

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: The cask is maintained by homebrew.   To install the formula we support, run `brew install powershell/tap/powershell`

comments.author: soyfrien
comments.body: Thank you, the tap's caveats were so useful. I didn't know about `/etc/shells` or `chsh`.

comments.body:
Great, yes, I was just looking for them.

```

% sudo echo '/usr/local/opt/powershell/bin/pwsh' >> /etc/shells

zsh: permission denied: /etc/shells

% sudo sh -c "echo '/usr/local/opt/powershell/bin/pwsh'>> /etc/shells"

%

```

You're a mind reader.
